questions.text: A woman presents with secondary infertility. She has had irregular cycles for 4-5 months. Her HSG is given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: She is suffering from genital tuberculosis

options.label: B
options.text: Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice

options.label: C
options.text: ZIFT is the modality of choice to treat her infertility

options.label: D
options.text: Infertility in this condition can be due to tubal damage

questions.correct_answer: C. ZIFT is the modality of choice to treat her infertility
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ZIFT is the modality of choice to treat her infertility ZIFT the modality of choice to treat her infertility is the incorrect option here . Image shows the tobacco pouch appearance in HSG.WHICH is seen in genital TB THE IOC here will be an endometrial biopsy . And Treatment will be ATT and IVF. Zygote intrafallopian transfer is not used to treat her infertility as her tubal cilia undergo irreversible damage. IVF will be indicated in her.

Highyeild:

Zygote Intrafallopian Transfer (Zift) Zygote intrafallopian transfer was first described by Devroey et al. (1986). The placement of the zygote (following one day of in vitro fertilization ) into the fallopian tube can be done either through the abdominal ostium by laparoscope or through the uterine ostium under ultrasonic guidance. This technique is a suitable alternative to GIFT when the defect lies in the male factor or in cases of failed GIFT. Results (29–30%) are similar to that of IVF. GIFT or ZIFT is avoided when tubal factors for infertility are present . The risk of ectopic pregnancy is high for GIFT and ZIFT compared to IVF.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - All other options are true. Option A. She is suffering from genital tuberculosis is true Option B. Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice is true Option D. Infertility in this condition can be due to tubal damage is correct.

Extraedge:

Mnemonic for uses of IVF in females- T Tubal infertility R Recanalisation after tubal sterilisation O Ovarian failure or diminished ovarian reserve (using donor oocytes) C Females with Cancers or on Chemotherapeutic drugs. A AIDS in partner R Risk of transmitting genetic disease to offspring S Surrogate motherhood if patient has no functional uterus.

questions.text: Which is not an assisted reproduction technique:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Artificial insemination All methods of ART, by definition, involve interventions to retrieve oocytes. These techniques include IVF, ICSI, GIFT, ZIFT, Cryopreserved embryo transfers, and the use of donor oocytes. Different methods of ART

Highyeild:

Intrauterine Insemination (IUI): Intrauterine insemination is the placement of 0.3mL of washed processed and concentrated sperm (devoid of seminal plasma)/semen into the intrauterine cavity by transcervical catheterization. The purpose of IUI is to bypass the endocervical canal and to place an increased number of motile sperms close to the fallopian tube. Components of the ejaculate removed in IUI include seminal fluid, excess debris, leukocytes, and morphologically abnormal sperms. The best results are achieved when the final specimen contain s 10 million total motile sperms . Indication: Intrauterine insemination is done i n males with: Severe hypospadias Retrograde ejaculation (Immediate postcoital urine is taken and sperms are extracted from it.) Neurogenic impotence Sexual dysfunction Oligospermia Asthenospermia Low ejaculate volume In female infertility, IUI is useful in: Cervical infertility–Antisperm antibodies are present in the cervix Vaginismus (involuntary contraction of perineal muscles during intercourse) Unexplained infertility.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option C: IVF - ET In vitro fertilization and embryo transfer Option A: GIFT Gamete intra-fallopian transfer Option B: ZIFT Zygote intrafallopian transfer

Extraedge:

Assisted Reproduction Technique : ART encompasses all the procedures that involve the manipulation of gametes and embryos outside the body for the treatment of infertility. Assisted Reproductive Techniques (Art) IVF-ET In vitro fertilization and embryo transfer GIFT Gamete intra-fallopian transfer ZIFT Zygote intra-fallopian transfer POST Peritoneal oocyte and sperm transfer TET Tubal embryo transfer zone SUZI Subzonal insemination ICSI Intracytoplasmic sperm injection AH Assisted hatching IVM In vitro maturation of oocyte PGD Preimplantation genetic diagnosis Cryopreserveration embryo/oocyte/ovarian tissue/ sperm Gestational Surrogacy SPERM RETRIEVAL TECHNIQUES TESE Testicular sperm extraction MESA Microsurgical epididymal sperm aspiration PESA Percutaneous epididymal sperm aspiration

questions.text: Artificial insemination with the husband’s semen is indicated in all the following situations, except:

options.label: C
options.text: Antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucus

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Azoospermia Azoospermia is the correct option here, as the question asks about the husband's semen. IUI may be either artificial insemination of the husband's semen called a s homologous insemination or artificial insemination of donor semen called Heterologous insemination . Husband’s semen is commonly used. The purpose of IUI is to bypass the endocervical canal which is abnormal and to place an increased concentration of motile sperm as close to the fallopian tubes

Highyeild:

Intrauterine Insemination (IUI): Intrauterine insemination is the placement of 0.3mL of washed processed and concentrated sperm (devoid of seminal plasma)/semen into the intrauterine cavity by transcervical catheterization. The purpose of IUI is to bypass the endocervical canal and to place an increased number of motile sperms close to the fallopian tube. Components of the ejaculate removed in IUI include seminal fluid, excess debris, leukocytes, and morphologically abnormal sperms. The best results are achieved when the final specimen contain s 10 million total motile sperms . Indication: Intrauterine insemination is done i n males with: Severe hypospadias Retrograde ejaculation (Immediate postcoital urine is taken and sperms are extracted from it.) Neurogenic impotence Sexual dysfunction Oligospermia Asthenospermia Low ejaculate volume In female infertility, IUI is useful in: Cervical infertility–Antisperm antibodies are present in the cervix Vaginismus (involuntary contraction of perineal muscles during intercourse) Unexplained infertility.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, B, and C are correct explanations for IUI.

questions.text: Following a full set of investigations in the fertility clinic, a couple is diagnosed as having unexplained infertility since all the tests have been reported as normal. The couple have been trying to conceive for 3 years. What treatment would be recommended?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In vitro fertilisation (IVF) In vitro fertilization (IVF) is the correct option . Offer IVF treatment to women with unexplained infertility who have not conceived after 2 years (this can include up to 1 year before their fertility investigations) of regular unprotected sexual intercourse.

Highyeild:

IVF : This is the most commonly done ART It involves ovulation induction, Oocyte retrieval, and fertilization of the oocytes in the laboratory ; embryos are then cultured for 3-5 days followed by their transfer to the endometrial cavity (ET) Indication of IVF in Females : Mnemonic for uses of IVF in females- T = T ubal infertility R = R ecanalisation after tubal sterilisation o = O varian failure or diminished ovarian reserve (using donor oocytes) c = F emales with Cancers or on Chemotherapeutic drugs. A = A IDS in partner R = R isk of transmitting genetic disease to offspring s = S urrogate motherhood if patient has no functional uterus. INDICATION OF IVF In Male Infertility: When the sperm count is < 5 million/ml Repeated IUI failure Multifactor infertility Unexplained infertility

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: no role of conservative management as the couple is trying for 3 years ( > 1 year). Option C: do not offer oral ovarian stimulation agents (such as clomifene citrate, anastrozole, or letrozole) to women with unexplained infertility. Option D: ICSI is indicated In Females with Tubal blockage Hostile cervical mucus Unexplained infertility.

questions.text: Prior to a frozen embryo transfer, a woman takes a course of oestradiol valerate to induce endometrial proliferation. She attends for an ultrasound scan after 10 days to measure the endometrial thickness. What endometrial thickness should have been achieved in order for the embryo transfer to proceed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 mm Replacement of embryos into a uterine cavity with an endometrium of less than 5 mm thickness is unlikely to result in a pregnancy and is therefore not recommended.

Highyeild:

EMBRYO TRANSFER in IVF : The fertilized ova at the 6–8 blastomere stage are placed into the uterine cavity close to the fundus about 3 days after fertilization. Not more than three embryos are transferred per cycle to minimize multiple pregnancies. Excess oocytes and embryos can be cryopreserved for future use. Luteal phase support is maintained with progesterone. It is started on the day after oocyte retrieval. hCG is given in supplemental doses (1,500–2,500 IU). Micronized progesterone 200 mg thrice a day oral or as a vaginal suppository (preferred) or progesterone in oil injection 50mg IM daily is continued for about 14 days. By this time diagnosis of pregnancy by estimation of b-hC (quantitative value) is possible. RISK with IVF : Risk of miscarriage Multiple pregnancies Ectopic Low birth weight baby and prematurity. The risk of congenital malformation of the baby remains similar to the general population. Other Options are not correct.

Solution:

1-I, 2-II,3-III, 4-IV 1 This involves ovarian stimulation and egg retrieval, followed by laparoscopically guided transfer of a mixture of two ova and 50,000 sperms into each of the fallopian tubes. I GIFT 2 One sperm is directly injected into each mature egg prior to intrauterine transfer of the fertilized eggs. II ICSI 3 involves the laparoscopic transfer of day 1 fertilized eggs into the fallopian tube. III ZIFT 4 This involves ovulation induction, oocyte retrieval and fertilization of the oocytes in the laboratory; embryos are then cultured for 3-5 days followed by subsequent transfer of selected fertilized oocytes transcervically under ultrasound guidance into the uterine cavity. Genetic study of polar body or embryonic cells may be required in a few cases. IV IVF Other Options are not appropriate.

questions.text: Match the appropriate treatment for the following patients:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-III, 2-1,3-II Oligospermia 10- 15million/ml IUI Oligospermia 5- 10million/ml IVF Severe oligospermia < 5million/ml ICSI Obstructive azoospermia ICSI Asthenospermia ICSI Other options are incorrect.

questions.text: Embryos are cryopreserved at low temperatures using:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liquid nitrogen Liquid nitrogen is used in Embryo cryopreservation. Involves cooling of embryos in the pronucleate stage or early cleavage stage to very low temperature in the presence of cryoprotectant. Cryopreservation of Embyo : Involves cooling of embryos in the pronuclear stage or early cleavage stage to very low temperature in the presence of cryoprotectants such as: I2 - Propanediol (Iodine) Glycerol Dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) with sucrose. They are then stored in liquid nitrogen till required. Over half the embryos survive the thawing process. Oocyte preservation has not been successful. No adverse effect s have been seen in babies born by this technique.
